message: Possibly a mobile app
I'm using a mobile app

I know Convore gets compared to campfire a lot, but a sexy and sleek Mac native app would definitely be welcome (think Propane). I would even pay a couple of dollars if I could d/l it from the App Store. Just a thought, since I am sure many of us are running this through a Fluid instance.
Just wondering if you guys have any idea of an app that utilizes convore API
@bradendouglass it's still up for debate whether Propane2 will include convore support or if it will be spun off into a separate app - but it's in progress
erhmm... I am asking of ideas
any suspected time on an android app?
im teaching some android classes at a local hackerspace - think the convore api is easy enough that i could use it in a tutorial class?

@kingcode I don't think the amount of new clients for twitter indicates anything other than the fact that for very many people, the officially released clients do the best job. Not perfect by any stretch (I still use Tweetie/Mac simply because it lets me choose a bigger damn font) but good enough that there's diminishing returns in doing it your own way.
well, he's taking this app thing as far as he can

@kingcode I don't see much hesitation about building on top of twitter - just today tapbots announced something. Like anything though, you'll likely see a rush of people releasing stuff. Over time the numbers dwindle - keeping an app alive takes commitment and unless you're making bags of cash or you're satisfying a burning personal need, you won't put in the effort.
i don't think i'd go that far, but i'm flattered you even asked the question
There's really a lot of interesting apps that you can build on top of Convore, but the only concern I hv is why should I?
@protocool I don't see the dwindling trends with Facebook but tapbot's new twitter product is only one I've heard for a really loooooooonnnnggggg time for a platform that once was very popular.

A white-label group messaging system. Developers would pay Convore to maintain the back-end systems, kind of the way Twillio works with phones/sms.  Convore makes money from this directly, so developers don't have to worry about Convore pulling a Twitter/App Store move on them.  As long as the features and reliability are solid and expanding, they'd be ahead of what most devs could create on their own.  And if the charges are low enough, it gives room for developers to monetize their apps and still make money.
@protocool ha, extremely unaware that propane2 was still in dev, thanks for the update!
event planning/organization. one topic per event, groups can be location- or subject-oriented
